Then, Christ will appear in glory with His full salvation for His lovers ([link]1 Pet. 1:5[/link], [link]7-9[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]4:13[/link]; [link]5:4[/link]).[br][br](2) From the side of the believers:[br][br]The believers, as God's possession, were chosen by God ([link]1 Pet. 1:1-2[/link]; [link]2:9[/link]), called by His glory and virtue ([link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]; [link]3:9[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:3[/link], [link]10[/link]), redeemed by Christ ([link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]), regenerated by God through His living word ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link], [link]23[/link]), and saved through the resurrection of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 3:21[/link]). They now are being guarded by the power of God ([link]1 Pet. 1:5[/link]), are being purified to love one another ([link]1 Pet. 1:22[/link]), are growing by feeding on the milk of the word ([link]1 Pet. 2:2[/link]), are developing in life the spiritual virtues ([link]2 Pet. 1:5-8[/link]), and are being transformed and built up into a spiritual house, a holy priesthood to serve God ([link]1 Pet. 2:4-5[/link], [link]9[/link]). They are God's chosen race, royal priesthood, holy nation, and peculiar people for His private possession to express His virtues ([link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]). They are being disciplined by His governmental judgment ([link]1 Pet. 1:17[/link]; [link]2:19-21[/link]; [link]3:9[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]4:6[/link], [link]12-19[/link]; [link]5:6[/link], [link]9[/link]), are living a holy life in an excellent manner and in godliness to glorify Him ([link]1 Pet. 1:15[/link]; [link]2:12[/link]; [link]3:1-2[/link]), are ministering as good stewards of His varied grace for His glorification through Christ ([link]1 Pet. 4:10-11[/link]) (under the elders' exemplary shepherding — [link]1 Pet. 5:1-4[/link]), and are expecting and hastening the coming of the Lord ([link]1 Pet. 1:13[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:12[/link]) in order to be richly supplied with an entrance into the eternal kingdom of the Lord ([link]1:11[/link]). Further, they are expecting the new heavens and new earth, in which righteousness dwells, in eternity ([link]v. 13[/link]), and they are growing continually in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ ([link]v. 18[/link]).[br][br](3) From the side of Satan:[br][br]Satan is the believers' adversary, the devil, who as a roaring lion is walking about, seeking someone to devour ([link]1 Pet. 5:8[/link]).[br][br](4) From the side of the universe:[br][br]The fallen angels were condemned and are awaiting eternal judgment ([link]2:4[/link]); the ancient ungodly world was destroyed by a flood ([link]2:5[/link]; [link]3:6[/link]); the ungodly cities were reduced to ashes ([link]2:6[/link]); the false teachers and heretical mockers in the apostasy and mankind in his evil living will all be judged unto destruction ([link]2:1[/link], [link]3[/link], [link]9-10[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]3:3-4[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 4:5[/link]); the heavens and the earth will be burned up ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]10-11[/link]); and all the dead men and the demons will be judged ([link]1 Pet. 4:5[/link]). Then the new heavens and new earth will come as a new universe, in which God's righteousness will dwell for eternity ([link]v. 13[/link]).[br][br]Paul in his writings also spoke concerning "these things" (except for the new heavens and new earth). Hence, Peter referred to Paul's writings to strengthen his own writings, especially concerning God's governmental and disciplinary judgment upon the believers. Paul strongly and repeatedly emphasized this matter in his writings ([link]1 Cor. 11:30-32[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:5-11[/link]; [link]2:3[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]; [link]6:8[/link]; [link]10:27-31[/link], [link]39[/link]; [link]12:29[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:13-15[/link]; [link]4:4-5[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:10[/link]). This must be the reason Peter highly commended Paul's writings.[br][br]What beauty and excellency are in this commendation! Although the Corinthians attempted to divide Peter and Paul according to their divisive preferences ([link]1 Cor. 1:11-12[/link]), Peter commended Paul, saying that Paul, like him, taught "these things" and that Paul's writings should not be twisted but should be regarded like "the rest of the Scriptures" and should receive the same respect as the Old Testament. For Peter to make such a commendation was not a small thing, for it was he who was rebuked to his face by Paul regarding the New Testament faith ([link]Gal. 2:11-21[/link]). This indicates that Peter was bold in admitting that the early apostles, such as John, Paul, and himself, although their style, terminology, utterance, certain aspects of their views, and the way they presented their teachings differed, participated in the same, unique ministry, the ministry of the New Testament ([link]2 Cor. 3:8-9[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]). Such a ministry ministers to people, as its focus, the all-inclusive Christ as the embodiment of the Triune God, who, after passing through the process of incarnation, human living, crucifixion, resurrection, and ascension, dispenses Himself through the redemption of Christ and by the operation of the Holy Spirit into His redeemed people as their unique portion of life and as their life supply and everything, for the building up of the church as the Body of Christ, which will consummate in the full expression, the fullness, of the Triune God, according to the eternal purpose of the Father.
This indicates that the mockers ([link]v. 3[/link]) and their followers must have twisted, not merely ignored ([link]v. 5[/link]), the Scriptures and the apostles' teaching.

See note [link]1[sup]5[/sup], point 2, in ch. 2[/link]. According to the context, [i]destruction[/i] here refers not to eternal perdition but to the punishment of the divine governmental discipline. See notes [link]18[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Pet. 4[/link] and [link book="2 Pet." chapter="3"]9[sup]5[/sup][/link] in this chapter.

verse.text: You therefore, beloved, since you know [i]these things[/i] beforehand, [note]1[/note]be on your guard lest being [note]2[/note]carried away by the error of the [note]3[/note]lawless, you [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]fall from your own [xref]b[/xref]steadfastness.
verse.note: Be on your guard because of the apostasy, the heretical teachings, which may carry you away to destruction by twisting the apostles' writings or the Scriptures ([link]v. 16[/link]).
The same word as that used in [link]Gal. 2:13[/link] concerning Peter, Barnabas, and other Jewish believers.
See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]. [i]The lawless[/i] must refer to the false teachers and mockers ([link]2:1[/link]; [link]3:3[/link]), who were the early heretics.
This is to become unstable ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: But [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]grow in the [note]2[/note]grace and [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. [note]4[/note]To Him be the [xref]c[/xref]glory both now and unto the day of eternity. Amen.
verse.note: This indicates that what Peter wrote in his two Epistles is a matter of life. To grow in grace is to grow by the bountiful supply of eternal life provided by the divine power ([link]1:3-4[/link]), and to grow in the knowledge of the Lord is to grow by the realization of what Christ is. This is to grow by the enjoyment of grace and the realization of truth ([link]John 1:14[/link] and note 6, [link book="John" chapter="1"]17[/link] and note 1).
See notes [link]14[sup]6[/sup] in John 1[/link], [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link], and [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 13[/link].

The realization of the knowledge of our Lord equals truth, the reality of all that He is, as in [link]John 1:14[/link], [link]17[/link] (see note [link book="John" chapter="1"]17[sup]1[/sup][/link] there). Peter charged the believers to grow not only in grace but also in this truth.

Referring to our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. Since such a praise is one that is rendered to our God ([link]Rom. 11:36[/link]; [link]16:27[/link]), it indicates that our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ is God.
